acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Based on its 96-hour LC50 of > 1000 mg/L for fish (carp), 48-hour EC50 of > 1000 mg/L for crustaceans (Daphnia magna), and 72-hour EC50 of > 900 mg/L for algae (Scenedesmus subspicatus) (IUCLID, 2000), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: The classification is based on the description that the LD50 for rabbits is > 20000 mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: It has been reported in rat tests that no mortality related to exposure to this substance is detected (PATTY (5th, 2001)); however, exposure concentrations were not provided and classification is not possible based on this report.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Its rat LD50 is >= 29000 mg/kg in all three tests documented (IUCLID (2000)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it is rapidly degradable (28-day BOD degradability = 79%, GC degradability = 89% (Biodegradation and Bioconcentration of Existing Chemical Substances under the Chemical Substances Control Law, 1993)), and its classification for acute toxicity is the "Not classified" category, the substance was classified into "Not classified".

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Its flash point is 116degC (IUCLID (2000)), which is above 93degC.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of in vivo test data. Regarding in vitro tests, Ames tests and chromosomal aberration tests both yielded negative results (IUCLID (2000)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine) which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Its autoignition point is 435degC (IUCLID (2000)), which is above 70degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: The substance was found to be a moderate irritant in rabbit tests (PATTY (5th, 2001). In other rabbit tests (OECD Guidelines 405), its scores for corneal clouding and conjunctival erythema were 1.72 and 2.67, respectively, leading to the conclusion that the substance is irritating (IUCLID (2000)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: The classification is based on descriptions that the substance was found to be a slight irritant in rabbit tests (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and it caused no irritation in other rabbit tests (OECD Guidelines 404) (IUCLID (2000)).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Human patch tests found that the substance is not sensitizing (IUCLID (2000)); however, test details are not provided and classification is not possible based on this report.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 21-day inhalation exposure tests using guinea pigs or dogs, no effects of exposure were noted at 2.8 mg/L/6h (90-day conversion value: 0.65 mg/L/6h), which falls under Category 2 guidance values (IUCLID (2000)). In 21-day inhalation exposure tests using rats, rough breathing and diarrhea were noted at 2.8 mg/L/6h (90-day conversion value: 0.65 mg/L/6h), which falls under Category 2 guidance values (IUCLID (2000)). In addition, in 1-month dermal administration tests using rats, hyperkeratosis of the skin and an increase in basal cells were detected; however, test details such as administration doses are not provided (IUCLID (2000)). Since effects of the substance in the range of guidance doses are not clear, it was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
